Address: 15 E Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV
Description/Theme: First establishment to receive a gaming license in 1931.
Notable Events: Renamed the Turf Club in 1943, then Monte Carlo Club in 1945.

Address: 15 E Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV 89101
Notable Events: Site of Vegas’s first gaming license (Northern Club); closed in 2016 for downtown redevelopment.

Address: 18 Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV 89101
Description/Theme: Historic downtown casino, sports/baseball theme in later years.
Notable Events: Originated 1930s; relocated in 1949; closed 2015 and demolished for Circa resort.

Address: 128 E Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV
Notable Events: World Series of Poker home.

Address: 129 Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV
Notable Events: World’s largest gold nugget.

Address: 600 E Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV
Notable Events: Oldest continuously operating casino.

Address: Las Vegas Blvd & Sahara Ave
Notable Events: First Strip hotel, destroyed by fire.

Address: 3120 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
Notable Events: Elvis's first Vegas gig.

Address: 3555 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
Notable Events: Bugsy Siegel project.

Address: 2755 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
Notable Events: Imploded 2000.

Address: 2535 Las Vegas Blvd S, Las Vegas, NV 89109
Ownership: Curacao Holdings, Sam Nazarian (SBE), Meruelo Group
Notable Events: Hangout of the Rat Pack in the 1960s; closed 2011 after 59 years, then reopened as SLS (2014–2017), restored to Sahara in 2019.

Address: 3355 Las Vegas Blvd S (now The Venetian)
Ownership: Jack Entratter, Howard Hughes, Sheldon Adelson
Notable Events: Hosted Sinatra’s Rat Pack, site of 1960 Vegas Summit in Ocean’s 11; imploded 1996 for The Venetian.

Address: 2901 Las Vegas Blvd S, Las Vegas, NV 89109
Ownership: Meyer Lansky, various public owners, last MGM/LVCVA
Notable Events: 60 years on Strip; featured in 'Casino'; demolished 2016 for Convention Center expansion.

Address: 2800 E Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV 89104
Ownership: J. Kell Houssels Jr., Harrah’s, Station Casinos
Notable Events: Famed for 106-lane bowling alley; rebranded to Castaways 2000; closed 2004, imploded 2005.

Address: 3801 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Ownership: Penn Entertainment, leased to Bally’s Corp
Notable Events: Folies Bergère for 50 years; slated for demolition in 2024 for new sports arena.

Address: 3600 Las Vegas Blvd S (now Bellagio site)
Ownership: Major Riddle, Morris Shenker, Steve Wynn
Notable Events: 35-ft sultan statue; bought by Steve Wynn, imploded 1993.

Address: 3000 Las Vegas Blvd S (now Resorts World)
Notable Events: World's largest casino at opening; mob skimming scandals; closed/demolished for Echelon/Resorts World.

Address: 2880 Las Vegas Blvd S, Las Vegas, NV 89109
Notable Events: Famous neon clown; live circus acts; family-oriented, later added hotel towers.

Address: 3570 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Notable Events: Heavyweight boxing, epic theming, opened 1966.

Address: 3667 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Notable Events: Formerly Tallyho (1962); Elvis & Priscilla wedding; closed/imploded 1997-98.

Address: 3667 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Ownership: London Clubs & Sommer Family, now Caesars/Planet Hollywood
Notable Events: Reopened April 2007 as Planet Hollywood after Aladdin bankruptcy.

Address: 3950 Las Vegas Blvd S (now Mandalay Bay)
Ownership: Warren Bayley, later Circus Circus Enterprises
Notable Events: Southernmost Strip hotel; imploded New Year’s Eve 1996.

Address: US Hwy 93, Boulder City, NV
Ownership: Circus Circus Enterprises, Nevada Restaurant Services (Dotty’s)
Notable Events: Gold Strike Inn 1958; fire and rebuild; rebranded 2015.

Address: 2900 Las Vegas Blvd S, Las Vegas, NV
Notable Events: World's largest motel at one time; cheap drinks and hot dogs; closed 2005 for Echelon/Resorts World.

Address: 3645 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
Notable Events: 1980 fire, later became Bally’s (now Horseshoe).

Address: 3645 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Notable Events: Opened as Bally’s after MGM fire; rebranded Horseshoe in 2022.

Address: 3000 Paradise Rd, Winchester, NV 89109
Ownership: Kirk Kerkorian, Hilton, now Westgate Resorts
Description/Theme: Modern high-rise luxury, no single theme.
Notable Events: Debuted as world's biggest hotel; Elvis residency 1969; Hilton then Westgate.

Address: 3730 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89158
Notable Events: CityCenter centerpiece; LEED Gold sustainability.

Address: 3600 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Description/Theme: Italian Bellagio village; elegance and fountains.
Notable Events: Dancing water fountains; world-class poker (Bobby's Room).

Address: 3131 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Notable Events: Steve Wynn’s flagship; Lake of Dreams.

Address: 3121 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Notable Events: Sister to Wynn, Forbes 5-Star.

Address: 3000 Las Vegas Blvd S, Winchester, NV 89109
Notable Events: Built on former Stardust site; three Hilton-branded hotels, huge LED globe.

Address: 3400 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Notable Events: First modern megaresort; closed 2023 for Hard Rock guitar hotel conversion.

Address: 3300 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Description/Theme: Pirate theme; later rebranded as TI with modern focus.
Notable Events: Pirate battle show until 2013; family-friendly, now more adult-oriented.

Address: 3770 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Description/Theme: Monte Carlo: European elegance; Park MGM: boutique modern.
Notable Events: Opened as Monte Carlo in 1996; complete renovation to Park MGM in 2018, NoMad tower addition.

Address: 3900 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89119
Notable Events: World's brightest beam of light; inclinators (diagonal elevators); major renovations and some de-theming.

Address: 3850 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Notable Events: Largest hotel in the world on opening; family-oriented, with joust tournaments and arcade.

Address: 3950 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89119
Notable Events: Wave pool and beach, Shark Reef aquarium, major events/conventions.

Address: 3799 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Description/Theme: Hollywood/Wizard of Oz theme at launch, now modern luxury.
Notable Events: Largest single hotel in Las Vegas (over 5,000 rooms); site of old Marina Hotel.

Address: 2000 Las Vegas Blvd S, Las Vegas, NV 89104
Notable Events: Tallest observation tower in the US; home to SkyJump, X-Scream, and other rides; rebranded to 'The STRAT' in 2020.

Address: 2777 S Las Vegas Blvd, Paradise, NV 89109
Notable Events: Project began 2007, stalled for years, finally opened 2023.

Address: 8 Fremont Street, Las Vegas, NV 89101
Notable Events: First new-build downtown in 40 years; world’s largest sportsbook, rooftop pool amphitheater (Stadium Swim); adults-only.

Address: 2000 Fashion Show Dr, Las Vegas, NV 89109
Notable Events: No gaming license; one of few Strip-adjacent hotels without a casino.

Address: 2411 W Sahara Ave, Las Vegas, NV 89102
Notable Events: Original 'The Casino' (1976), became Palace Station; infamous for O.J. Simpson robbery incident.

Address: 4949 N Rancho Dr, Las Vegas, NV 89130
Notable Events: Acquired by Station Casinos 2000; added movie theaters and ice rink.

Address: 2101 Texas Star Ln, North Las Vegas, NV 89032
Notable Events: Closed 2020, demolished 2022 after pandemic shutdown.

Address: 2400 N Rancho Dr, North Las Vegas, NV 89032
Notable Events: Closed during 2020 pandemic, never reopened; demolished 2022.

Address: 777 W Lake Mead Pkwy, Henderson, NV 89015
Notable Events: Closed during 2020 pandemic, demolished 2022.

Address: 5111 Boulder Hwy, Las Vegas, NV 89122
Description/Theme: Old West town theme, large atrium.
Notable Events: One of the first true locals casinos, continues as Boyd flagship.

Address: 12 E Ogden Ave, Las Vegas, NV 89101
Notable Events: Popular with Hawaiian tourists; 'the Cal' is a locals favorite for food and craps.

Address: 200 Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV 89101
Notable Events: Designed by Wayne McAllister; hosted Wayne Newton’s early gigs.

Address: 1 Main St, Las Vegas, NV 89101
Notable Events: Built on site of original Union Pacific depot; used as Biff’s in Back to the Future II.

Address: 1821 Las Vegas Blvd N, North Las Vegas, NV 89030
Notable Events: Known for its value and 24/7 restaurant.

Address: 2140 Las Vegas Blvd N, North Las Vegas, NV 89030
Notable Events: Bowling, small locals casino.

Casino Name: Lucky Club (Ojos Locos Sports Cantina y Casino)
Address: 3227 Civic Center Dr, North Las Vegas, NV 89030
Notable Events: Rebranded as Ojos Locos in 2023; heavy focus on Hispanic market.

Address: 2800 S Boulder Hwy, Henderson, NV 89002
Ownership: Joseph DeSimone, Nevada State Railroad Museum
Notable Events: Oldest continuously licensed casino in Nevada (opened just after gaming legalized in 1931).

Address: 920 N Boulder Hwy, Henderson, NV 89011
Notable Events: Formerly the Cattle Baron Casino.

Address: 444 W Sunset Rd, Henderson, NV 89011
Notable Events: Shares branding with the original Klondike (Strip).

Address: 725 S Racetrack Rd, Henderson, NV 89015
Notable Events: Locals’ favorite; off the tourist radar.

Address: 1741 N Boulder Hwy, Henderson, NV 89011
Notable Events: Affordable table games and a retro bar.

Address: 2757 Las Vegas Blvd N, North Las Vegas, NV 89030
Notable Events: Family-run since opening, known for its value.

Address: 1301 W Sunset Rd, Henderson, NV 89014
Notable Events: Features 70-lane bowling center, large multiplex theater.

Address: 2300 Paseo Verde Pkwy, Henderson, NV 89052
Notable Events: Site of the Discovery Channel’s 'American Casino' reality show.

Address: 11011 W Charleston Blvd, Las Vegas, NV 89135
Notable Events: Flagship for affluent Summerlin; highly rated resort and pool complex.

Address: 9777 Las Vegas Blvd S, Las Vegas, NV 89183
Notable Events: Hosts major rodeos, bowling events, and equestrian competitions.

Address: 4500 W Tropicana Ave, Las Vegas, NV 89103
Notable Events: Popular with locals for big bingo, theater, events.

Address: 4000 W Flamingo Rd, Las Vegas, NV 89103
Description/Theme: No major theme; value-oriented locals casino.
Notable Events: Next to the Rio; long poker and bowling tradition.

Casino Name: Rampart Casino at the Resort at Summerlin
Address: 221 N Rampart Blvd, Las Vegas, NV 89145
Ownership: Hoteles Dinamicos, leased by JW Marriott
Notable Events: Originally Regent Las Vegas; frequent ownership changes.

Address: 12300 Las Vegas Blvd S, Henderson, NV 89044
Notable Events: First major resort for residents south of the city, strong food reputation.

Address: 2121 E Craig Rd, North Las Vegas, NV 89030
Notable Events: Live music venue, popular North Las Vegas entertainment spot.

Address: 5255 Boulder Hwy, Las Vegas, NV 89122
Notable Events: Remains closed as of 2024 after pandemic shutdown.

Address: Multiple (notably 2700 E Fremont St, plus others)
Location Category: Various: Las Vegas, Henderson, Boulder Hwy
Notable Events: Dozen+ locations; include Boulder Highway, Rancho, Anthem, Fremont, Valley View, Lake Mead, Decatur, and more.

Address: 4178 Koval Ln, Las Vegas, NV 89109
Notable Events: Famously cheap steak specials, karaoke, microbrewery.

Casino Name: Silver Sevens Hotel & Casino (formerly Continental, Terrible’s)
Address: 4100 Paradise Rd, Las Vegas, NV 89169
Notable Events: Multiple name changes; major 2013 renovation to Silver Sevens.

Address: 5625 W Flamingo Rd, Las Vegas, NV 89103
Notable Events: Included for completeness; no full casino on premises.

Address: 217 Las Vegas Blvd N, Las Vegas, NV 89101
Notable Events: Closed 2013; now operates as a boutique hotel, bar, and co-working space (no casino).

Address: 206 N 3rd St, Las Vegas, NV 89101
Notable Events: Closed 2006, extensively remodeled, reopened as Downtown Grand in 2013.

Address: 206 N 3rd St, Las Vegas, NV 89101
Notable Events: Revival of the former Lady Luck, features rooftop pool (Citrus Grand Pool Deck).

Address: 2800 E Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV 89104
Notable Events: Famous bowling alley; demolished after 2004 closure.

Casino Name: Royal Inn / Royal Americana / Royal Hotel
Address: 99 Convention Center Dr, Las Vegas, NV 89109
Notable Events: Frequent name/ownership changes; demolished 2017.

Address: 899 Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV 89101
Notable Events: Once the cheapest tables downtown; shuttered 2012, now part of downtown development.

Address: 5255 Boulder Hwy, Las Vegas, NV 89122
Notable Events: Demolished for Eastside Cannery.

Address: 3799 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Notable Events: Became base for MGM Grand (current), lobby structure remains.

Address: 3750 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Notable Events: Famous roller coaster marquee; demolished for CityCenter/Aria.

Address: 5195 S Las Vegas Blvd, Las Vegas, NV 89119
Notable Events: Last Strip casino before entering from south, demoed for Welcome to LV sign park.

Address: 2955 Las Vegas Blvd S, Las Vegas, NV 89109
Notable Events: Howard Hughes owned; demoed for The Mirage.

Address: 3475 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Notable Events: Renamed Harrah’s in 1992, major renovations.

Address: 3475 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Notable Events: Famous for celebrity tribute shows and events.

Address: 3535 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Notable Events: Notorious for car collection and unique history; became The Quad, then The Linq.

Address: 3535 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Notable Events: Renamed from Imperial Palace via 'The Quad'; home to the High Roller observation wheel.

Address: 3535 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV 89109
Notable Events: Interim name between Imperial Palace and The Linq.

Address: 4575 Boulder Hwy, Las Vegas, NV 89121
Notable Events: Sister property to Arizona Charlie's Decatur; built for value-focused locals market.

Address: 740 S Decatur Blvd, Las Vegas, NV 89107
Notable Events: Popular for bingo; part of Golden Entertainment chain.

Address: 5111 Boulder Hwy, Las Vegas, NV 89122
Notable Events: Remains an anchor of the Boulder Strip casino corridor.

Address: 5288 Boulder Hwy, Las Vegas, NV 89122
Notable Events: Known for value meals and no-frills atmosphere.

Address: 120 Market St, Henderson, NV 89015
Notable Events: Billed as the ‘jewel of Henderson’, Irish pub and slot parlor.

Address: 140 S Water St, Henderson, NV 89015
Notable Events: Formerly Eldorado Casino; rebranded The Pass Casino in 2021.

Address: 3333 Blue Diamond Rd, Las Vegas, NV 89139
Notable Events: Famed for its aquarium with mermaid shows, Bass Pro Shop attached.

Address: 777 W Lake Mead Pkwy, Henderson, NV 89015
Notable Events: Closed during COVID, demolished 2022.

Address: 2101 Texas Star Ln, North Las Vegas, NV 89032
Notable Events: Closed during COVID, demolished 2022.

Address: 900 W Bonanza Rd, Las Vegas, NV 89106
Notable Events: First integrated casino in Vegas, closed after six months; site remains historic.

Address: I-15 at Jean, Jean, NV
Notable Events: Sister to Gold Strike Jean, demoed for industrial park.

Casino Name: Gold Strike Hotel and Gambling Hall (Jean)
Address: I-15 at Jean, Jean, NV
Notable Events: Now Terrible's; last casino before California border when Primm casinos closed temporarily.

name: Aladdin Hotel & Casino
address: 3667 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
notes: Renamed from Tally Ho in 1966; closed in 1997 and imploded in 1998 [oai_citation:82‡neonmuseum.org](https://neonmuseum.org/news/history-of-the-demolished-hotels-in-las-vegas/#:~:text=The%20Aladdin%20Hotel%2C%20opened%20in,new%20project) [oai_citation:83‡neonmuseum.org](https://neonmuseum.org/news/history-of-the-demolished-hotels-in-las-vegas/#:~:text=In%202000%2C%20a%20new%20Aladdin,still%20occupies%20the%20site%20today). New Aladdin/Planet Hollywood built on site.

name: Barbary Coast / Bill’s Gamblin’ Hall
address: 3595 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
notes: Operated as Barbary Coast (1979–2007) [oai_citation:84‡casino.fandom.com](https://casino.fandom.com/wiki/Barbary_Coast_Hotel_and_Casino#:~:text=Fandom%20casino,188), then Bill’s Gamblin’ Hall (2007–2013). Closed for renovation into Cromwell [oai_citation:85‡wizardofvegas.com](https://wizardofvegas.com/articles/cromwell-las-vegas/#:~:text=Cromwell%20Las%20Vegas%20,be%20Gansevoort%2C%20but%20a).

name: Boardwalk Hotel & Casino
address: 3750 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
notes: Opened as a Holiday Inn (1960s), became Boardwalk in 1989 [oai_citation:86‡historiclasvegasproject.com](https://historiclasvegasproject.com/Boardwalk-Hotel-and-Casino.html#:~:text=The%20Holiday%20Inn%20opened%20in,1966). Closed 2006 and imploded later that year [oai_citation:87‡historiclasvegasproject.com](https://historiclasvegasproject.com/Boardwalk-Hotel-and-Casino.html#:~:text=Boardwalk%20Hotel%20and%20Casino%20closed,on%20January%209%2C%202006); now part of CityCenter/Aria.

name: Bourbon Street Hotel & Casino
address: 120 E Flamingo Rd, Paradise, NV
notes: Initially the ill-fated Shenandoah project (1980). Opened as Bourbon Street in 1985 [oai_citation:88‡historiclasvegasproject.com](https://historiclasvegasproject.com/Bourbon-Street-Hotel-and-Casino.html#:~:text=Shenandoah%20Hotel%20opened%20in%201980). Closed in 2005 [oai_citation:89‡historiclasvegasproject.com](https://historiclasvegasproject.com/Bourbon-Street-Hotel-and-Casino.html#:~:text=Closed%20on%20October%2018%2C%202005); imploded in January 2006 [oai_citation:90‡neonmuseum.org](https://neonmuseum.org/news/history-of-the-demolished-hotels-in-las-vegas/#:~:text=Despite%20their%20best%20efforts%2C%20the,serves%20as%20a%20parking%20lot).

name: California Club
address: 101 E Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV
notes: Small downtown casino (no hotel) catering to locals [oai_citation:91‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_Club_(casino)#:~:text=Location%20Las%20Vegas%20%2C%20,115.14472) [oai_citation:92‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_Club_(casino)#:~:text=The%20California%20Club%20operated%20from,after%20the%20purchase%20by%20Wynn). Sold to Steve Wynn in 1973 and incorporated into the Golden Nugget.

name: Castaways Hotel & Casino (Showboat)
address: 2800 E Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV
notes: Opened as the Showboat (1954), a locals casino/bowling center. Renamed Castaways in 2000, closed in 2004. Imploded on January 11, 2006 [oai_citation:93‡neonmuseum.org](https://neonmuseum.org/news/history-of-the-demolished-hotels-in-las-vegas/#:~:text=Originally%20opened%20in%201954%20as,homage%20to%20the%20historic%20property).

name: Castaways Casino (Strip)
address: 3333 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
notes: Formerly Sans Souci Auto Court (opened 1950s). Became the Castaways on the Strip; closed July 20, 1987 [oai_citation:94‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castaways_(casino)#:~:text=match%20at%20L187%20property%20with,Boulder%20Highway%2C%20starting%20in%202001). Demolished for The Mirage opening in 1989.

name: Clarion Hotel & Casino (Greek Isles)
address: 305 Convention Center Dr, Winchester, NV
notes: Opened 1970 as Royal Inn [oai_citation:95‡neonmuseum.org](https://neonmuseum.org/news/history-of-the-demolished-hotels-in-las-vegas/#:~:text=Courtesy%3A%20NBC%20News). Later names included Paddlewheel, Debbie Reynolds Hollywood, and Greek Isles. Last operated as Clarion (2009–2015); imploded in 2015 [oai_citation:96‡neonmuseum.org](https://neonmuseum.org/news/history-of-the-demolished-hotels-in-las-vegas/#:~:text=Courtesy%3A%20NBC%20News).

name: Cotton Club
address: 500 Jackson Ave, Las Vegas, NV
notes: Historic Westside casino for African Americans [oai_citation:97‡ccgtcc-ccn.com](https://www.ccgtcc-ccn.com/Westside.pdf#:~:text=The%20Cotton%20Club%20opened%20as,wasn%E2%80%99t%20long%20before%20a%20blackjack) [oai_citation:98‡ccgtcc-ccn.com](https://www.ccgtcc-ccn.com/Westside.pdf#:~:text=yellow%20pages%20ad%20is%20a,Clarence%20Ray%20deals%20Blackjack%20at). Opened by Moe Taub in 1944; offered slots, keno, and later table games. Closed by the late 1950s as Westside gaming declined.

name: El Morocco Club
address: 1322 North H St, Las Vegas, NV
notes: An interracial Westside nightclub & casino active in the mid-20th century [oai_citation:99‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,El%20Rancho%20Vegas). Known for jazz and gambling under one roof. Closed by the end of the 1950s; building later repurposed.

name: Fiesta Henderson (The Reserve)
address: 777 W Lake Mead Pkwy, Henderson, NV
notes: Opened as The Reserve in 1998, renamed Fiesta Henderson in 2001 [oai_citation:100‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,Fitzgeralds%20Casino%20Hotel%20Las%20Vegas). Closed permanently in 2020 due to COVID-19 impacts; Station Casinos demolished the property in 2022 [oai_citation:101‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,Fitzgeralds%20Casino%20Hotel%20Las%20Vegas).

name: Fiesta Rancho
address: 2400 N Rancho Dr, North Las Vegas, NV
notes: Opened as Fiesta Rancho (Texas Station’s sister property) in 1994. Never reopened after the 2020 pandemic shutdown. Station Casinos imploded it in 2022 [oai_citation:102‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,Vegas); license relinquished.

name: Fitzgeralds Casino Hotel
address: 301 Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV
license_status: Active (rebranded as The D Las Vegas)
notes: Opened in 1980 (previously the Sundance). Operated as Fitzgeralds from 1987 to 2012. After a brief closure/renovation in late 2012, it re-opened as The D Las Vegas [oai_citation:103‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,Fitzgeralds%20Casino%20Hotel%20Las%20Vegas) under the same license.

name: Gold Spike Casino
address: 400 E Ogden Ave, Las Vegas, NV
notes: A 112-room downtown hotel-casino known for low limits. Opened 1976; last operated by Siegel Group. Closed in 2013 when sold for redevelopment [oai_citation:104‡vegaschanges.com](https://vegaschanges.com/category/permanently-closed-casinos/#:~:text=,The%20D). Reopened as a boutique hotel/bar (no casino).

name: Hard Rock Hotel & Casino
address: 4455 Paradise Rd, Paradise, NV
notes: Popular rock-themed off-Strip resort [oai_citation:105‡vegaschanges.com](https://vegaschanges.com/category/permanently-closed-casinos/#:~:text=,La%20Bayou). Closed 2020 after purchase by new owners. Property gutted/remodeled and re-opened in 2021 as Virgin Hotels Las Vegas (with a new tribal gaming license) [oai_citation:106‡vegaschanges.com](https://vegaschanges.com/category/permanently-closed-casinos/#:~:text=,La%20Bayou).

name: Holy Cow Casino & Brewery
address: 2423 Las Vegas Blvd S, Las Vegas, NV
notes: Opened in 1992 as Nevada’s first microbrewery casino. Featured ~150 slots and a bar. Shut down in 2002 due to declining business [oai_citation:107‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,Holy%20Cow%20Casino%20and%20Brewery). The building was later demolished; no casino now on site.

name: Key Largo Hotel & Casino
address: 377 E Flamingo Rd, Paradise, NV
notes: A  Key West-themed locals casino (formerly Ambassador Inn). Renamed Key Largo in 1997, offering ~300 slots and a few table games. Closed in 2005 amid financial issues [oai_citation:108‡vegaschanges.com](https://vegaschanges.com/category/permanently-closed-casinos/#:~:text=,Las%20Vegas%20Club); demolished in 2007.

name: Klondike Hotel & Casino (South Strip)
address: 5191 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
notes: Opened 1976 in a converted motel. Small  slot casino famous for its neon Klondike sign [oai_citation:109‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=K). Closed in 2006 for a failed redevelopment project; ultimately demolished. (Land remains vacant in 2025.)

name: Klondike Sunset Casino
address: 444 W Sunset Rd, Henderson, NV
notes: Opened as Tom’s Sunset Casino (1989) [oai_citation:110‡historiclasvegasproject.com](https://historiclasvegasproject.com/Klondike-Sunset-Casino.html#:~:text=Tom%27s%20Sunset%20Casino%20opened%20on,August%202%2C%201989); became Klondike Sunset in 1999 [oai_citation:111‡historiclasvegasproject.com](https://historiclasvegasproject.com/Klondike-Sunset-Casino.html#:~:text=Tom%27s%20Sunset%20Casino%20closed%20in,1998). Closed 2014 after owner’s death, then reopened under new ownership on Aug 3, 2016 [oai_citation:112‡historiclasvegasproject.com](https://historiclasvegasproject.com/Klondike-Sunset-Casino.html#:~:text=Klondike%20Sunset%20Casino%20closed%20in,2014). Continues to operate as a locals casino.

name: La Bayou (Northern Club)
address: 15 E Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV
notes: One of Vegas’s oldest gaming locations. Held the city’s first license in 1931 as the Northern Club [oai_citation:113‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,77). Later known as Monte Carlo Club and Coin Castle, then La Bayou from 2002. This tiny slots-only casino closed in 2016 when Derek Stevens bought the parcel [oai_citation:114‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,75).

name: Lady Luck Hotel & Casino
address: 206 N 3rd St, Las Vegas, NV
notes: Opened 1964 (as Honest John’s), became Lady Luck in 1968. Closed for remodeling in 2006 and sat dormant [oai_citation:115‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,67). The license was preserved through temporary gaming. Reopened in Oct 2013 as Downtown Grand (license transferred to new owner).

name: Landmark Hotel & Casino
address: 364 Convention Center Dr, Winchester, NV
notes: Futuristic 31-story tower near the Convention Center. Struggled financially despite famous marquee. Closed in 1990 [oai_citation:116‡neonmuseum.org](https://neonmuseum.org/news/history-of-the-demolished-hotels-in-las-vegas/#:~:text=); imploded in 1995 [oai_citation:117‡neonmuseum.org](https://neonmuseum.org/news/history-of-the-demolished-hotels-in-las-vegas/#:~:text=). Now a Las Vegas Convention Center parking area.

name: Lucky Dragon Hotel & Casino
address: 300 W Sahara Ave, Las Vegas, NV
notes: Boutique Asian-oriented casino with 27,500 sq ft gaming [oai_citation:118‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,Casino). Failed to draw enough revenue; closed after 23 months. Went bankrupt and reopened as Ahern Hotel (no casino) in 2019.

name: Lucky Club / Ojos Locos Casino
address: 3227 Civic Center Dr, North Las Vegas, NV
notes: Opened 1999 as Speedway Casino [oai_citation:119‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ojos_Locos_Sports_Cantina_y_Casino#:~:text=The%20casino%20opened%20in%20March,casino%20having%20expanded%20to%20over); became Lucky Club in 2008. In 2022–23 it was renovated into a Latino-focused venue. Reopened February 6, 2023 as Ojos Locos Sports Cantina y Casino [oai_citation:120‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ojos_Locos_Sports_Cantina_y_Casino#:~:text=the%20focal%20point.,28) (same license, rebranded).

name: Mermaids Casino
address: 32 E Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV
notes: Opened 1956 as Silver Palace (Fremont’s first all-slot casino), later Carousel and Sassy Sally’s. Renamed Mermaids in 1999 with  slots, no tables. Closed in 2016 along with La Bayou [oai_citation:121‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,75) for the Circa project.

name: Mint Hotel & Casino
address: 100 E Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV
notes: Opened in 1957 as an elegant 300-room hotel-casino [oai_citation:122‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,Moulin%20Rouge%20Hotel). Famous for its 26-story tower added in 1965. The Mint was acquired by Binion’s Horseshoe in 1988 and closed; its tower became part of Binion’s [oai_citation:123‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,Moulin%20Rouge%20Hotel).

name: Monte Carlo Resort & Casino
address: 3770 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
notes: A 3,000-room Strip megaresort opened in 1996. Operated as Monte Carlo until a 2016–2018 rebranding to Park MGM [oai_citation:124‡vegaschanges.com](https://vegaschanges.com/category/permanently-closed-casinos/#:~:text=,Now%20Park%20MGM). The property never fully closed, but the **Monte Carlo** name/license was retired in 2018.

name: Moulin Rouge Hotel & Casino
address: 900 W Bonanza Rd, Las Vegas, NV
notes: Historic first integrated casino in Las Vegas. Opened to great acclaim in May 1955, but financial troubles forced it to close after only 6 months [oai_citation:125‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,Moulin%20Rouge%20Hotel). Sporadic attempts to reopen failed; building burned down in 2003.

name: Nevada Palace Casino
address: 5255 Boulder Hwy, Las Vegas, NV
notes: A locals casino on Boulder Highway with  slots and bingo. Closed in 2008 [oai_citation:126‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,75) when Boyd Gaming demolished it to build Eastside Cannery on the site. (Eastside Cannery opened Aug 2008; closed in 2020, currently inactive.)

name: Old Vegas (Old Nevada)
address: 2440 Boulder Hwy, Henderson, NV
notes: Western-themed amusement park and small casino in Henderson [oai_citation:127‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Vegas#:~:text=Old%20Vegas%20was%20approved%20by,sale%20to%20television%20producer%20Burt). Offered a faux Old West town with a saloon casino. Opened late 1978, but fell into bankruptcy and closed by 1987. Later redeveloped (no casino).

name: Opera House Casino & Saloon
address: 2542 Las Vegas Blvd N, North Las Vegas, NV
notes: Small North Las Vegas casino known for bingo and cheap drinks. Opened 1995; by 2014 it had closed (license lapsed) [oai_citation:128‡vegaschanges.com](https://vegaschanges.com/category/permanently-closed-casinos/#:~:text=,Riviera%20Hotel%20%26%20Casino). Building was sold and repurposed (no gaming there currently).

name: Pair-O-Dice / 91 Club
address: Highway 91 (Las Vegas Blvd S at Sahara), Paradise, NV
notes: Las Vegas Blvd’s first casino: the Pair-O-Dice nightclub opened in 1931. Renamed the 91 Club in the 1940s. Ceased operations by 1948 when the Thunderbird opened nearby. Paved the way for modern Strip resorts.

name: People’s Choice Casino
address: 805 W. Owens Ave, Las Vegas, NV
notes: A small West Las Vegas casino owned by Sarann Knight-Preddy. Opened mid-1960s in the segregated Westside district [oai_citation:129‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/People%27s_Choice_Casino#:~:text=Address%20805%20West%20Owens%20Las,Preddy). Offered slot machines and possibly table games for local patrons. Closed by the end of the 1960s.

name: Pioneer Club
address: 25 E Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV
notes: Classic downtown casino famous for the Vegas Vic neon cowboy. Operated from 1942 to 1995 [oai_citation:130‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=%2A%20Pair,Pioneer%20Club%20Las%20Vegas). After 53 years, its casino closed in ’95 and the space turned into a souvenir store. (Vegas Vic remains atop the building.)

name: Queen of Hearts Hotel & Casino
address: 202 N. 5th St (Las Vegas Blvd N), Las Vegas, NV
notes: Opened 1963 as Casbah Hotel & Casino [oai_citation:131‡neonmuseum.org](https://neonmuseum.org/news/history-of-the-demolished-hotels-in-las-vegas/#:~:text=Image%3A%20Ann%20Meyer%20Queen%20of,Hearts). Renamed Queen of Hearts in 1990, offering low-cost rooms and slots. Closed in 2010; the aging motel-casino was demolished to make way for the new City Hall site [oai_citation:132‡neonmuseum.org](https://neonmuseum.org/news/history-of-the-demolished-hotels-in-las-vegas/#:~:text=budget%20prices,fully%20shed%20its%20troubled%20past).

name: Railroad Pass Hotel & Casino
address: 2800 S. Boulder Hwy, Henderson, NV
notes: Opened in 1931 and still operating, Railroad Pass is one of Nevada’s oldest continuously licensed casinos. Located near Boulder City (annexed into Henderson in 2014). *Included here due to its historic license (omitted previously).*

name: Royal Nevada Hotel & Casino
address: 3000 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
notes: A short-lived Strip resort with a “Royal” theme. Opened in 1955 but was financially unsuccessful. Closed in 1957 and was eventually absorbed by the adjacent Stardust resort [oai_citation:133‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,85) (became the Stardust’s Convention Center).

name: Sahara (SLS) Las Vegas
address: 2535 Las Vegas Blvd S, Las Vegas, NV
notes: The Sahara operated from 1952 until May 2011. Under new ownership it reopened in 2014 as **SLS Las Vegas**, then reverted to the **Sahara** name in 2019. Continuous license, but the interim SLS brand (2014–2019) was missing in the original data [oai_citation:134‡vegaschanges.com](https://vegaschanges.com/category/permanently-closed-casinos/#:~:text=,Now%20Park%20MGM).

name: Sands Hotel & Casino
address: 3355 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
notes: The famed Sands hosted the Rat Pack and many classic performances. Closed in 1996 and imploded in November 1996 [oai_citation:135‡neonmuseum.org](https://neonmuseum.org/news/history-of-the-demolished-hotels-in-las-vegas/#:~:text=match%20at%20L173%20,SANDS%20%E2%80%93%201996). The Venetian now occupies its site.

name: Silver City Casino
address: 3001 Las Vegas Blvd S, Winchester, NV
notes: Opened as Riata Casino, renamed **Silver City** in 1975. A smaller Strip casino (slots only in later years). Closed on Halloween 1999 [oai_citation:136‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,91); the gaming license was given up and the building was converted to retail space.

name: Silver Nugget Casino
address: 2140 Las Vegas Blvd N, North Las Vegas, NV
notes: North Las Vegas casino with bowling and events. Opened mid-1950s, long known for low-price bingo and food. Closed during the March 2020 COVID lockdown and did not reopen [oai_citation:137‡youtube.com](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fs-soir-IbM#:~:text=Silver%20Nugget%20Casino%20closed%20since,the%20COVID%20lock%20down). As of 2023 the property remains closed and its nonrestricted license is inactive [oai_citation:138‡yogonet.com](https://www.yogonet.com/international/news/2020/08/20/54377-north-las-vegas-39-silver-nugget-requests-closure-extension-through-july-2021#:~:text=,July%20of%202021).

name: Silver Slipper Casino
address: 3200 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
notes: A small Strip casino renowned for its rotating neon shoe sign. Operated from 1950 until 1988, when it was purchased by Margaret Elardi (and later Steve Wynn) and closed [oai_citation:139‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,91). Demolished; now part of Wynn Las Vegas frontage.

name: Silverbird / El Rancho (1982)
address: 2755 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
notes: This north Strip property was the Thunderbird (1948–1977), then **Silverbird** (1977–1981), then **El Rancho Casino** (1982–1992) [oai_citation:140‡neonmuseum.org](https://neonmuseum.org/news/history-of-the-demolished-hotels-in-las-vegas/#:~:text=match%20at%20L234%20,RANCHO%20%E2%80%93%202000). Closed in 1992 and stood vacant. Imploded on October 3, 2000 [oai_citation:141‡neonmuseum.org](https://neonmuseum.org/news/history-of-the-demolished-hotels-in-las-vegas/#:~:text=Las%20Vegas%20Strip%2C%201986%2C%20UNLV,Special%20Collections).

name: Slots-A-Fun Casino
address: 2890 Las Vegas Blvd S, Winchester, NV
notes: A tiny Strip casino next to Circus Circus, known for cheap gaming in the 1980s-90s. Formerly had table games and its own license. Now operates with only a handful of slot machines and a bar. Technically still a nonrestricted license, but no table games remain.

name: South Coast (South Point) Casino
address: 9777 Las Vegas Blvd S, Enterprise, NV
notes: Coast Resorts opened this 660-room property as **South Coast** in early 2006. It was sold to Michael Gaughan and rebranded **South Point** in October 2006 [oai_citation:142‡lasvegas.fandom.com](https://lasvegas.fandom.com/wiki/Alphabetical_list_of_casinos#:~:text=). The resort has remained open continuously (only the name/licensee changed).

name: The Western Hotel & Casino
address: 899 E Fremont St, Las Vegas, NV
notes: Low-roller casino (room rates $8/night) in downtown’s seedy east end. Opened 1970, it was famous for penny slots and 99¢ breakfasts. Closed in 2012 due to declining business and downtown redevelopment plans [oai_citation:143‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=W). Building still stands vacant.

name: Treasure Island Hotel & Casino
address: 3300 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
notes: Opened by MGM as a family-themed pirate resort in 1993 [oai_citation:144‡historiclasvegasproject.com](https://historiclasvegasproject.com/Treasure-Island-Hotel-Casino.html#:~:text=Project%20historiclasvegasproject,with%20The%20Sirens%20of). Still operating as **TI** (Treasure Island), now under Phil Ruffin’s ownership. *Note: Already in original dataset; included here for completeness if it was mistakenly omitted.*

name: Tropicana Las Vegas
address: 3801 Las Vegas Blvd S, Paradise, NV
notes: A classic Rat Pack-era resort. Continuously operated from 1957 [oai_citation:145‡neonmuseum.org](https://neonmuseum.org/news/history-of-the-demolished-hotels-in-las-vegas/#:~:text=Image%3A%20front%20facade%20of%20the,tropicana%20las%20vegas%20at%20night). In 2024, its owner (Bally’s Corp) announced the Tropicana will close and be imploded for a baseball stadium [oai_citation:146‡neonmuseum.org](https://neonmuseum.org/news/history-of-the-demolished-hotels-in-las-vegas/#:~:text=). As of mid-2025 the casino is still open but slated to cease operations by Oct 2024.

name: Vacation Village Hotel & Casino
address: 6711 Las Vegas Blvd S, Enterprise, NV
notes: 127-room motor inn casino at the far south Strip. Known for a 50¢ buffet and locals bingo. Closed in 2002 after bankruptcy [oai_citation:147‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,98). Demolished in 2003. The land was later used partly for South Point’s equestrian arena and remains mostly undeveloped.

name: Vegas World
address: 2000 Las Vegas Blvd S, Las Vegas, NV
notes: Bob Stupak’s space-themed casino known for wild promotions. Closed in 1995 to undergo a $550M transformation into the Stratosphere tower resort [oai_citation:148‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Defunct_casinos_in_the_Las_Vegas_Valley#:~:text=,98). The new Stratosphere opened in 1996 with a fresh license/ownership (Stupak had sold majority control).

name: Wild Wild West Gambling Hall
address: 3330 W Tropicana Ave, Spring Valley, NV
notes: A Station Casinos-owned truck stop casino and 260-room motel. Opened 1998 just west of I-15. Shut down permanently in 2022 for a planned mixed-use redevelopment [oai_citation:149‡vegaschanges.com](https://vegaschanges.com/category/permanently-closed-casinos/#:~:text=,Wild%20Wild%20West%20Casino). Buildings were demolished in 2023; license returned to the state.
